conclusion: Analyze the data in the image to determine the relationship between trials, book divisions, and force required to pull out book B.
The image is a table showing three columns: 'Number of trials,' 'Number of book divisions,' and 'Force F (N).' The values in the 'Force F (N)' column are 4.5, 10.5, 22.5, and 46.5, respectively.
Problem involves two identical books, A and B, each weighing 5N, divided into equal parts and alternately stacked on a smooth table.
A horizontal force F is applied to pull out book B, which is fixed in place.
Coefficient of kinetic friction, μ, is defined as the ratio of sliding friction force f to pressure N.
Since books are divided equally, pressure N on each division is 5N.
As number of divisions increases, force required to pull out book B also increases, suggesting frictional force f increases with divisions.
Assuming coefficient of kinetic friction μ is constant between any two sheets of paper.
Force F required to pull out book B is proportional to number of divisions, as each division adds to frictional force.
Since μ is constant, the value of μ is 0.9.
